Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Mobile Application Security through Remote Sandboxing and Cloud Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The last few years have witnessed an explosive growth in the number of personal mobile devices, such as smartphones and tablets. This growth has been followed by an even more exceptional increase in the download of mobile applications, as well as in the related security threats. In this context, the cloud computing paradigm can be leveraged to improve mobile application security. The fundamental idea is to install the mobile application on a remote server in the cloud infrastructure rather than on the device. Then the application can be accessed with techniques similar to remote desktop computing. This approach is referred to as remote sandboxing.

The major advantage of this scheme is that it is very suitable to efficiently offer advanced security features. To this end, remote sandboxing is complemented with a framework for cloud-based security services tailored to mobile applications. The framework supports heterogeneous mobile devices and platforms, and provides methods to improve the resource utilization of the cloud infrastructure. Furthermore, it provides energy-efficient and reliable support for remote networking of mobile devices.

The remote sandboxing framework will enable a new cloud delivery model, where security services specific to mobile applications are offered to the users. It will also benefit cloud computing by improving efficiency in resource allocation and management, as well as by fostering research on security. Finally, the research will promote the awareness of security threats and privacy issues affecting personal devices, and include activities targeted to undergraduate and K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data and application security offers the biggest challenge in mobile cloud computing environments. Existing security mechanisms such as malware and virus detection are computationally expensive for battery powered mobile devices which can, however, offload security services to the cloud computing infrastructure. This EAGER project proposed remote sandboxing approach in which mobile applications are encapsulated in a virtual environment in the cloud, and transparently accessed by mobile users through a remote connection. Remote sandboxing can effectively secure mobile applications while enabling a flexible solution for the cloud provider to offer value-added security services targeted for the mobile devices.

Major activities of this projected included the design and development of: (i) energy-efficient data collection and aggregation schemes in sensor cloud environments; (ii) dynamic detection and removal of access conflicts in the cloud; (iii) cloud service provider selection to assess data breach security risks; (iv) trust models and information reliability in cloud-assisted, smartphone-based participatory sensing; and (iv) privacy and authentication mechanism in cloud-based pervasive computing.

Key outcomes include numerous publications in high quality journals and conferences. Three PhD students were trained through this project in cutting-edge research and all of them completed their degrees. One PhD student received a Best paper Award in an international conference. Six underfgraduate students were also trained; one of them coauthored a journal article with the PI and a Ph.D. student.  Several keynote talks and invited presentations were also delivered reporting results of this project.
